entry.title: The Truth About the Fall Real Estate Market
entry.content:
Real estate is a local animal, so why does the media always use sweeping generalities when it talks about the market? Today, Iâ€™ll give you a quick breakdown about whatâ€™s really going on.

Buying a home? Click here to perform a full home search
Selling a home? Click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation 
Call me at (518) 861-7016 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation

How is the market doing? How will the election affect the market? Should you buy or sell in the fall? Iâ€™ve heard all of these questions lately, so I wanted to address them today.

First, I would like to point out that I read two articles about the real estate market last week. One said that the real estate market was still going gangbusters, while the other said that the market was starting to slow down and that a shift is on the horizon. So, which of those two articles is right? 

The truth is that they both are. The media loves generalities. Thatâ€™s why you see so many headlines that say now is a great time to sell or that the market is starting to slow down. However, real estate is a local animal, and there are many factors that affect the market in each city, town, and neighborhood.

Some of those factors include job growth, population growth, interest rates, and property taxes. How is the local economy doing? Some pockets in our area tend to do very well while others do poorly. It all depends on your local real estate market.
At the end of the day, whatever is happening in your specific area is what really matters.
As for the election â€” it really does not matter who is in office. It is very difficult for changes at the federal level to trickle all the way down to your local real estate market. The local government is much more important. For example, areas like Colonie are doing very well right now because there are positive things happening in the community and they have great schools.

At the end of the day, it really matters where you are. Generally speaking, I can tell you that our market is still seeing good activity. We are in one of the stronger markets we have seen since the market peak in 2006. In most areas, homes priced below $300,000 are in a sellerâ€™s market, while homes priced around the $400,000 or $600,000 mark are in a buyerâ€™s market.

Remember, the median home price in our region is $200,000; as you go above that price point, the number of people who can afford those homes drops, which is why we start to see that buyerâ€™s market in the higher price points.

If you are interested in the specifics about your town or neighborhood, just give me a call or send me an email. I would be happy to give you a more detailed, statistical report. I look forward to hearing from you!

link.title: The Truth About the Fall Real Estate Market

entry.title: When Is Renting Smarter than Buying?
entry.content:
We constantly get the question of whether renting or buying is better in New York. It's actually better to rent if you plan on moving within the next two years.

Buying a home? Click here to perform a full home search
Selling a home? Click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation 
Call me at (518) 861-7016 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation

We're constantly asked whether people are better off buying or renting a home. I've probably read 100 articles on this topic, so I wanted to give you my insight.

New York state has some of the highest closing costs in the country, but buying a home is a great option because it has great tax benefits, it provides a great quality of life, and it's the American Dream to own a piece of the United States. However, if you're planning on moving within the next two years, renting is generally a better option for you.


â€œ
If you're planning on moving in the next two years, renting is generally the better option.
â€



That's why on my team, we'll sit down and ask you how long you plan on being in a house. If it's less than two years, generally we're going to tell you that renting is a better option for you. 

I've also seen people plan on staying in a home for 10 years but then something suddenly changes with their marriage, job, or neighborhood. So here's what I'm offering to you.

If you buy a house from us and your situation changes (marital situation, you don't like the neighbors, you get a new job, etc.) and you have to sell within a year, I will sell your house for free. I'll help you get out of that house for no charge at all.

 If you have any questions about your own situation and you're not sure if you're better off renting or buying, give me a call or send me an email. I'd love to help you out!

entry.title: Buyerâ€™s Agents vs. Listing Agents
entry.content:
Home buyers often make the mistake of thinking that they will save money by working with the listing agent directly or skipping an agent altogether.

Buying a home? Click here to perform a full home search
Selling a home? Click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation 
Call me at (518) 861-7016 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation

Today I wanted to talk about some misconceptions people have about buyerâ€™s agents and listing agents.

The main thing people donâ€™t understand about buyerâ€™s agents is that you donâ€™t have to pay them a commission. Buyers' agent's are paid a 2.5% commission by the seller. Buyers also donâ€™t realize that as a licensed real estate broker, our buyerâ€™s agents can show any home listed on the market. Even if the property is listed as For Sale By Owner or is listed by a different real estate agent, our buyerâ€™s agent can still show you the property.

Buyers often make the mistake of thinking that they will save money by working with the listing agent directly. Listing agents represent the seller; the last thing you want to do as a buyer is go to the sellerâ€™s agent to represent you. The sellerâ€™s agent is generally going to charge the same commission as the buyerâ€™s agent. Not only will working with the sellerâ€™s agent not save you money, you also wonâ€™t have anyone working for you whose fiduciary responsibility is to represent your best interests.

Another thing to keep in mind is that buyerâ€™s agents are generally not good listing agents and listing agents are generally not good buyerâ€™s agents. On my team, we specialize; you are either a buyerâ€™s agent or a listing agent. For the most part, I work with sellers. I will occasionally work with a buyer if one is referred to me, but my goal is to list homes and market them. A buyerâ€™s agentâ€™s goal is to get you the perfect home at the cheapest price as quickly as possible.

Why do you want to work with a buyerâ€™s agent? You want someone with great negotiating skills. I recently worked with a buyer who was trying to purchase an estate. The owner had $1.8 million in the property and the appraisal came back at $1.3 million. It took a long time to negotiate, but I was able to get that property for our buyer for about $600,000â€”a fraction of the appraised value. Not only did they get a great deal, but they should also net a lot of money down the road when the time comes to sell.

The bottom line that you need to remember is that generally, a listing agent is not a good buyerâ€™s agent and vice versa. If you are buying a home, you need an agent who specializes in working with buyers. If you are selling a home, you need an agent who specializes in selling homes. That is what our team does.

â€œ
A listing agent does not make a good buyerâ€™s agent and vice versa.
â€

If you have any questions about purchasing a home in todayâ€™s market or about real estate in general, give me a call or send me an email. My team and I would be happy to help you!

entry.title: Is the First Offer on Your Home the Best Offer?
entry.content:
Today Iâ€™d like to Mythbust one of the most common questions I get, which is, â€œIs the first offer you receive on a home always the best offer?â€
In my experience, the first offer you get on your house is the best offer about 80% of the time. If youâ€™re a buyer in that dangerous period during the first few weeks that the home is on the market and you are serious about buying the home, you really need to put a serious offer in right away.
A client of ours recently received a full-price offer from a well-qualified buyer and was wondering whether he should accept it or wait for others to come in. We advised him to take it. This is a good situation to be in, and if itâ€™s a good offer, you wonâ€™t want to risk losing it. If you find yourself in this situation as a seller, your first inclination may be to wait for better offers to come in. This is a bad idea. Hereâ€™s why:
A few weeks ago, another one of our clients received a full-price offer on his home before we even got the â€œFor Saleâ€ sign in on his front lawn. This seller decided not to take this offer because the home had not been listed on the MLS yet. Two weeks and 18 showings later, the overwhelming feedback was, â€œThe home is overpriced.â€
Unfortunately, weâ€™re going to end up selling this home for less than full price, even though the homeowner originally had a full-price offer in his hand. Hindsight is 20-20, but even though we recommended that the seller take the original offer, the reality is that waiting for other offers is going to cost this seller between $10,000 and $15,000.
To answer the original question, most of the time, the first offer you receiveâ€”unless itâ€™s completely unreasonableâ€”is going to be the best offer. In general, the longer a home sits on the market, the lower the offers are on it.

â€œ
The longer a home sits, the lower the offers on it will be.
â€
If youâ€™re a buyer and youâ€™re looking to buy a home thatâ€™s been sitting on the market for over 60 days, you may be able to go in with a bit of a lower offer. In todayâ€™s low-inventory market, though, if a home has been on the market for just a few weeks and youâ€™re serious about it as a buyer, you will want to make a serious offer right away.
As far as this myth goes, Iâ€™d say that the statement, â€œThe first offer is the best offerâ€ is generally confirmed in most cases.

entry.title: The Difference Between an Inspector and an Appraiser
entry.content:
Today I wanted to talk about the difference between an appraiser and a home inspector. The role of a real estate appraiser is to value the property for the bank before you get a loan. As a former appraiser, I can tell you that a state-certified appraisal is completely different from a broker market analysis.

The home inspector works for you. The inspection costs around $500 and lasts for about two hours. The inspector goes through the house top to bottom, looking for defects like structural damage, carbon monoxide leaks, electrical problems, or foundation issues, to name a few.

â€œ
The home inspector works for you, so find a great one.
â€


If you're buying a home, you don't want to cut corners and hire anything but the best home inspector that you can. Ask friends, family members, and, most importantly, your Realtor for recommendations. You don't want to buy a money pit!

If you need a recommendation for a great inspector or you have any questions at all about real estate, please don't hesitate to give me a call or send me an email. I look forward to hearing from you!

How can you use real estate to cut your tax bill?

No one likes to pay more taxes than they have to, and real estate is a great vehicle to cut taxes down. The government loves when people invest in real estate and gives out favorable tax cuts to those who do so.  

I often read about potential home buyers who pay $1,000 a month in rent fretting that if they buy a home, then their mortgage will only increase that monthly payment to $1,400. What they donâ€™t know is that homeowners can deduct both their property taxes and their mortgage interest rate. When you figure those two things in, your effective cost often ends up being less than what you were paying in rent.

Favorable tax treatment not only extends to single-family homes but also to income properties. I just bought an income property, and itâ€™s going to give a 40% cash-on-cash return. That figureâ€™s going to be hard to replicate in todayâ€™s stock market, but the point is that this is in stark contrast to investment properties, which are depreciated over 27.5 years. Depreciation is a non-cash expense, meaning that even if the propertyâ€™s tax is positive when you calculate the depreciation expense, it may actually show a loss.

Iâ€™m also flipping a house right now. Unfortunately, my personal income taxes are very high, but when Iâ€™m flipping a house, I only have to pay the capital gains tax, not the social security or self-employment taxes. The gains on the flip, then, will be much lower than my ordinary income tax rate.


â€œ
You absolutely must own real estate to get ahead in todayâ€™s market.
â€


If youâ€™re a high-income earner or a first-time home buyer, give me a call or send me an email and let me show you how real estate can save you money on your tax bills and why you absolutely must own it to get ahead in todayâ€™s market.

entry.title: How Can You Protect Your Investments From Events Like Brexit?
entry.content:

Selling a home? Click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation

Today I wanted to talk a little about Brexit, the U.K.â€™s decision to leave the European Union. The night before the vote, Wall Street predicted that the U.K. would stay but those who wanted to stay lost by a 2% margin.

Wall Street does not like uncertainty and, if you have a 401K, you probably felt some real pain the Friday after the vote came through, especially considering that the market fell by 800 points. Thatâ€™s why today, I want to talk about building wealth.

As a society, weâ€™re trained to put money into our 401Ks when a single event, like Brexit, can entirely decimate your portfolio. How can you make yourself immune to global events or insane behavior on the stock market?

I am fortunate to know many multi-millionaires. These people have made money in the real estate market, not the stock market. They understand the stock market and they do not like not having control of their money.

Stocks are a very important part of any portfolio, but I think you also need to invest in some real estate. No matter what is happening in the world, someone still has to rent an apartment. Not only that, real estate is tangible wealth. You can even add value to it by making certain upgrades.



In fact, Iâ€™m closing in two days on a multi-family rental. That property will have huge positive cash flows. If I bought that building for $170,000 in cash, my return would be 13.75%, even after I pay out taxes, insurance, and more. I would still have a better return than I would in the stock market, and thatâ€™s not even including appreciation on the building! Thatâ€™s the beauty of real estate.

As money flows out of stocks and into bonds in the wake of Brexit, mortgage rates have come down. Now is a great time to take out a 15 to 30-year mortgage.

If I buy that building, which is 20% down and figure $5,000 or $6,000 in closing costs, thatâ€™s about a $40,000 investment. After I pay my debt service on that mortgage and my property taxes, my return is 40% on that $40,000. In about two years, I will have my entire investment on that property back. Again, that is not including appreciation.

When you figure in the equity build-up, appreciation, and positive tax returns over the course of that mortgage, my return on investment is close to 50% on that building.

If youâ€™re not investing in real estate right now, I really think you should consider it. Itâ€™s a great way to diversify your portfolio and become more immune to the stock market and other events that could decimate your 401K.

entry.title: Cut Your Mortgage by 8 Years With This Trick
entry.content:
Buying a home? Click here to perform a full home search
Selling a home? Click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation 
Call me at (518) 861-7016 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation

I wanted to share an important tip with you. I guarantee that it will literally save you tens of thousands of dollars if you own a home or you're thinking about buying a home.

It's a secret your banker won't tell, and quite frankly, doesn't want you to know. The secret is how you can pay off a 30-year mortgage in 22 years.


It's really simple. All you need to do is make one extra mortgage payment a year. Sure, you could save money with interest rates as low as they are by getting a better rate with a 15-year mortgage, but the payment jumps up substantially. Payments on 15-year mortgages are a lot harder on families with two kids, car payments, and student loans, for example.

So the trick is to go with a 30-year option, and make one extra payment each year. That will cut your mortgage down by eight years! Think about what this would do for your cash flow!

You might be thinking you don't know if you can save up an extra payment every year. There's another trick to make that aspect easier, too. You can do this by making bi-weekly mortgage payments. Since most people get paid every two weeks, you can have half of your mortgage payment taken out of each check - most banks will set this up for you for free. If you get paid every two weeks, that means you get paid 26 times a year. This slowly builds an extra month's worth of payments into total payments over the course of a year. You'll still pay off your mortgage eight years early.

If you have any questions on how this works, please feel free to call me. I'd be happy to answer any questions you have.

link.title: Cut Your Mortgage by 8 Years With This Trick

Everyone knows that sellers donâ€™t want to give their home away. They always say they can come down on the price later if they have to. On the other hand, buyers donâ€™t want to overpay for the house. They usually start with a lowball offer and will negotiate upwards if they have to. 

In our current market, good pricing for a seller is imperative to maximize your return. For buyers, what you offer makes the difference between you getting the home or not.

On the buying side, I understand why you donâ€™t want to overpay for a home. However, I bought my home 15 years ago. I overpaid for my home by $3,000, but it was the home I wanted. Over the last 15 years, my home has appreciated by at least six figures. That $3,000 didnâ€™t matter. 

In todayâ€™s market, if you want to get a house and youâ€™re competing against multiple offers, you really need to put your best offer forward. If the home just came on the market, that means offering list price or more. 

Even though I overpaid by $3,000 on my home, that only added an extra $15 a month to my mortgage payments. Keep that in mind when making an offer on your dream home. We can run a market analysis to make sure that you donâ€™t overpay for the home, but keep in mind that the days of the lowball offer are over. 


As a seller, you need to price your home right. In todayâ€™s market, homes are selling at 95% to 97% of list price. That means you need to price your home within 95% of a buyerâ€™s perceived value in order to sell. Pricing high and planning to come down later is a good way to net less money on your home sale.

In the past week, Iâ€™ve put four homes under contract. They all sold at or above list price. Thatâ€™s because we priced them right, marketed them well, and drew multiple offers to get our sellers the best price possible. 

The bad news is that there were two homes that the banks did not appraise. The appraisals came in lower than market value. 

Ultimately, price your house right and you will net the most money. Buyers need to put strong offers in.

entry.title: Watching This Video Could Save Your Life
entry.content:
Buying a home? Click here to perform a full home search
Selling a home? Click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation 
Call me at (518) 861-7016 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation

Winter approaches in Albany. As we turn on the heat, watch out for two hidden dangers inside your home: carbon monoxide and radon. With these dangerous gasses, it can be a matter of life and death.

If you run a gas furnace or have an attached garage, it's important to know common sources of carbon monoxide. Carbon monoxide could seep into your home from a failed gas furnace or a car running too long in your garage.

Carbon monoxide is a colorless, odorless gas that will send you unconscious quickly. A bird could build a nest in the chimney during the summer, and block the exhaust, for instance. It's common this time of year to read a news story about a carbon monoxide fatality or injury. Take precaution. It doesn't have to happen in your home.

New York law requires homeowners to have carbon monoxide alarms. Detectors are affordable at any home improvement store. If you cannot afford one, give me a call and I will pick one up for you. It is crucial to have a carbon monoxide detector inside your home!


Radon, another colorless, odorless gas, could also be inside your home. Radon comes from radium decay through rocks and minerals in the soil. You cannot buy a monitor, but the state can provide you with a radon test kit. These test kits are also available at home improvement stores for usually $11. A reading over 4pCi/l is considered dangerous.

Radon is the number one cause of lung cancer in the United States. If your radon levels are too high, you will need to get a mitigation system. This removal process costs $1,200 to $1,800.

It's incredibly important to test for radon and have a carbon monoxide detector. If you already have a carbon monoxide detector, change the batteries routinely. If you have any questions for me, or if you need a carbon monoxide detector, give me a call or send me an email. I would be happy to help you!

link.title: Watching This Video Could Save Your Life

entry.title: Is Price More Important than the Terms in an Offer?
entry.content:
Buying a home? Click here to perform a full home search
Selling a home? Click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation 
Call me at (518) 861-7016 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation

Today, I want to talk about something we always talk about, whether you're a buyer or seller. For some reason, people always focus on the price. That drives me wild sometimes because price is not the only factor to consider in the home buying transaction. When negotiating, we always encourage you to look at price and terms. Sometimes, the terms are more important than the price. You have to look at the big picture.

Here's an example for buyers. I've seen buyers negotiate for three days, and then they got the deal they wanted. They got 1,000 bucks less than what they expected to. That's great! But then, they go to the same bank they've always done business with to handle the financing. They don't shop around, and wind up paying a quarter point more on a 30-year mortgage.


Guess what? If you do that, you've just blown that 1,000 bucks you spent three days negotiating for, and then some! That quarter point will cost you way more money than $1,000 over the next 30 years.

As for sellers, we see you guys holding out for top dollar all the time. Then, we take a look at the seller's situation, and it turns out they're moving into a new construction home. The reality is, they have to move into temporary housing before their new home is ready. So sure, you get the bragging rights of getting top dollar, but you have to move twice.

In the long run, the inconvenience and cost of temporary housing probably cost more than getting that top dollar. It might have made more sense to take a lower offer with a closing period that allowed them to move directly into the new construction property.

Ultimately, my thought for the day is this: Don't focus solely on price. Think about your carrying costs or mortgage costs. As your real estate agent, we will help you consider the offer from every angle in order to save you money in the long run.


If you have any questions, give me a call or send me an email. I would be happy to help you!

link.title: Is Price More Important than the Terms in an Offer?

Our team has been lucky to be very successful in the real estate world, and people are wondering what makes us successful. Today I want to tell you a little bit about me and why I have succeeded in real estate. 



Only a few short years ago, I was unemployed and struggling to support my family. I sat down and wrote down what I wanted in life and what I was willing to give up for it. Since then, I have surrounded myself with and tried to learn from the best, and my goal is to always strive to be better. 

It's easy to stay even with the pack and enjoy mild success. It's very difficult to struggle, to fail, and get back up again. When you are used to winning in life, you're going to get complacent when you realize there is always someone out there working harder than you. 

I ran cross country in high school, but didn't have a lot of natural ability. Every day after school, I would run a grueling 1.5 miles up a steep hill. There is nothing harder to do, but the dedication made me a better runner and allowed me to compete at a higher level. I kept working at it, and didn't let my failures indicate my future performance. 

Succeeding in anything comes down to hard work and sacrifice. It's not easy to succeed in life, but you can as long as you learn from your failures, and persevere through them. It's always darkest before the dawn.

entry.title: How Much Can You Expect to Pay for Closing Costs in New York?
entry.content:
Buying a home? Click here to perform a full home search
Selling a home? Click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation 
Call me at (518) 861-7016 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation

What are closing costs in New York state? This is a question I've received A LOT recently, so I thought I would take the time to answer it today. Unfortunately, in the state of New York, closing costs are more expensive than anywhere in the country. 

As a buyer, costs will fluctuate substantially depending on the lender. Lender fees, bank fees, and attorney fees, among others, will be included when you close. The mortgage recorded tax will cost you 1-1.25%; if you take out a mortgage for $300,000, for example, you will have to pay the state at least $3,000 just for the right to take that mortgage out. 

You also have to pay title insurance, which is based on the price of the home and can run several thousand dollars. Additionally, the lender may ask you to put up a year's worth of taxes in escrow - that's cash you need to come up with on the spot! When you add all these factors together when buying a home, the closing costs can run you up to 5% when buying in our state.

Fortunately, it's a whole lot cheaper on the selling end. The attorney fee is generally between $500-700, and you'll typically owe a couple hundred dollars for a transfer tax. Unfortunately, there is an additional closing cost where you will pay for an abstract or title search for the buyer in Schenectady County. Other than these fees, there really isn't much else!

If you have any questions about the buying or selling process, or if you need real estate assistance of any kind, give us a call or shoot us a quick email. We would love to hear from you!

entry.title: How to Avoid Costly Damages to Your Home This Winter
entry.content:
There are many great Albany homes for sale. Click here to perform a full home search, or if you're thinking of selling your home, click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation so you know what buyers will pay for your home in today's market. You may also call me at (518) 861-7016 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.

Although it's the dead of winter, the real estate market is incredibly active. We're seeing multiple offers on homes that are priced right and other positive signs for our market, especially considering the tough winter we've had. Today, I want to share a few tips on keeping your home in good condition during these crazy months.

First, icicles are NOT good for your home! They may be pretty, but they are a sign of ice dams, which can cause some serious leaking that you want to avoid. It's incredibly important to get up and clear the snow within three feet of the edge of the roof. Once you do that, the melting snow will be able to run off as it's supposed to.

What causes these ice damns? A lot of the problems stem from a lack of insulation in the attic area. I've been in many houses where I've seen insulation stuffed in the eaves and soffits of the attic. Homeowners will explain that they did that because they saw daylight coming in and wanted to correct it. My advice: you need to have air flow from your soffits up to your ridge vent! Your attic should be cold - the circulation of air is vitally important if you want to prevent ice dams on your roof. 

Another problem we've seen lately is mold in attics. A lot of times, especially in older homes, contractors have vented bathroom fans into the attic, which effectively dumps more moist air into attic space, causing heat buildup and eventually mold. My advice: check to make sure your bathroom fans are vented out through the roof to avoid mold buildup in your attic.

If you have any questions about winterizing your home, don't hesitate to give us call or shoot us a quick email. We're real estate professionals, so we deal with this stuff all the time and would love to give you a hand! We look forward to helping you soon.

Thanks, and make it a great day!

link.title: How to Avoid Costly Damages to Your Home This Winter

We've reached the end of January, and unfortunately that means your property tax bill is due. I cannot change the due date of your bill, but I have some helpful tips in order for you to pay a little less in taxes this year and also in 2016.

What I've noticed is that a lot of homes in Albany are overvalued, which means that you'll end up paying more taxes. Be sure to check the assessment of your home and file the proper grievances if you don't agree with what your home is valued at. We can help you file a grievance - it's a free service we offer in order to serve you. 

Another thing I'm noticing in Albany is that not many homeowners are taking advantage of the Star Savings Program, which will impact the school taxes that you owe in September. Everyone is eligible for the Star Savings Program as long as you have a primary residence and your income is less than $500,000 per year. Go to your town's assessor and ensure that you have that exemption in place. 

If you are 65 or over, you are then eligible for the Enhanced Star Program. Contact us or your municipality in New York for assistance with applying for that program. 

Veterans also should be aware of the Veterans' Exemption, which applies to combat and non-combat veterans. The exact qualifications vary by municipality, but be sure to ask us or contact your local municipality.

If you have any questions about this topic, or if you would like to know anything about the real estate market in Albany, please don't wait to call or email us. Our full-time professional staff will be eager to help you in any way possible.

entry.title: What Does the New Casino Mean for Schenectady Home Values?
entry.content:
There are many great Albany homes for sale. Click here to perform a full home search, or if you're thinking of selling your home, click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation so you know what buyers will pay for your home in today's market. You may also call me at (518) 861-7016 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.

Thanks for joining us once again! I know how valuable your time is and I promise not to squander it! 

As we wrap up 2014, it's time to recap what we saw in real estate over the last 12 months and take a look at what we can expect moving forward. I will also address the new casino going up in Schenectady and discuss the impact it will have on our community.  

In 2014, we saw median home prices get back to where they were in 2007, at around $200,000. The average days on market was about 90 days, while the volume of home sales fell by about 5%. We want to say thanks to everyone who did business with us this year, as we were up about 25% in 2014. Your business is truly appreciated! 

Now, what about that new casino going up in Schenectady? Will it have any impact on home values in the area? Here are my thoughts: When Global Foundries was announced, people assumed it would cause property values to rise and many feel the same way about the casino.

The casino will be a huge bonus for any of the businesses that support it - restaurants and movie theaters, for example. The casino will also contribute about $8.1 million in property taxes and help homeowners in Schenectady City, as well as the county. However, it is not going to have an effect on home values - your home values will not rise as a result of the casino being built. 

The 1,200 jobs that the casino creates are not enough to increase the demand for homes enough to increase the prices substantially. Most of those jobs will likely come from people in the area. To really change home values in our area, we need a larger influx of jobs. We're seeing many people move to Texas, Florida, and North Carolina - they are leaving Schenectady to live in more affordable places. When there are more people moving away from our community than are moving to it, an increase in home values is unlikely.

Overall, the casino will have a positive impact on local businesses, the local economy, and will ease the tax burden of homeowners. However, we will not see home values improve as a direct result of the new casino.

If you have any questions give me a call any time. I'm always happy to talk real estate. Thanks, and make 2015 your best yet!

link.title: What Does the New Casino Mean for Schenectady Home Values?

entry.title: Are You Leaving Money on the Table by Waiting Until Spring to Sell?

You may also call me at (518) 861-7016 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.

Welcome back everyone! We want to say thanks to everyone who came out to our Thanksgiving Pie Giveaway, it was really nice to see you.

Today, we want to discuss listing your home during the holiday season. Whether buying or selling, people often put off their real estate needs until after December. Many people think the spring is the best time to buy, so they figure they'll just wait. We feel like this is a huge mistake.

Now is a great time to sell for a number of reasons:
  • Inventory is at its lowest point.
  • Buyers are serious.
  • Your home looks great during the holidays.
  • Interest rates may rise next year.
  • You'll have to compete with your neighbors in the spring.
There is a lot of great activity in the Albany market right now. In fact, we've listed five homes this week! Putting your home on the market now, before everyone else does, is generally a winning strategy. If you do what everyone else does, you're going to get what everyone else does: average returns. 

If you're interested in taking advantage of these favorable selling conditions, don't hesitate to reach out to us. We would love to sit down and discuss your options.

Also - we want to say CONGRATULATIONS to Ben for winning our Thanksgiving raffle for a 32" TV! We hope you enjoy it!

entry.title: The Question of Added Value via Solar Panels
entry.content:
There are many great Albany homes for sale. Click here to perform a full home search, or if you're thinking of selling your home, click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation so you know what buyers will pay for your home in today's market. You may also call me at (518) 861-7016 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.

The Question of Added Value via Solar Panels

Hey everyone, welcome back to our blog. We created this blog to share with you some of our knowledge and some of the experiences we have had in order for you to be more informed in your next real estate endeavor. 

Today's topic: solar panels. We are often asked, probably about 6 or 7 times in the last month alone, if solar panels do in fact add value to your home. 

The quick answer is no. At the current time, they do not add value as we are actually seeing buyers who are adverse to the look of the home with solar panels on the front. If you put them on the back of the home, they don't negatively affect the home's value, but they do if they are on the front. 

As solar panels become more widely accepted in the future, this will go away, but the panels, at the current time, do not add value. If you are going to be in your home for a while, by all means go get them and enjoy the cost savings, but if you are just looking for a way to add value to your home before you sell it, this is probably not the route to go. 

If you have any questions for us, please feel free to give us a call or send us an email. We would love to help you out.

link.title: The Question of Added Value via Solar Panels

Albany Real Estate Market Update for Fall 2014

Today we would like to talk to you briefly about the fall real estate market here in Albany. We are seeing some great activity right now. We put 3 homes under contract just today, 1 of them with multiple offers.

A common misconception about the spring market is that it's the best time to sell. That couldn't be further from the truth. The fall market is generally more active than the spring market. Last year, we actually sold 360 more homes in the fall than we did in the spring. 

If you are, however, set on waiting for the spring, it's never too early to call us to talk about getting you a consultation so we can see what you need to do in order to get your home ready for the spring market. If you are thinking about buying this fall, give us a call or email as well.

entry.title: Albany Real Estate Market Update for August 2014
entry.content:
There are many great Albany homes for sale. Click here to perform a full home search, or if you're thinking of selling your home, click here for a FREE Home Price Evaluation so you know what buyers will pay for your home in today's market. You may also call me at (518) 861-7016 for a FREE home buying or selling consultation to answer any of your real estate questions.

Albany Real Estate Market Update for August 2014

Today we want to talk to you about what's going on in the Albany real estate market.  Right now, we are hearing conflicting data regarding home prices. National reports are saying that home prices are up 10%, but local reports state that home prices in Albany are down over 25%.

So what's really going on? The market is currently segmented.  In areas where price points are over $300,000, we consider that a buyer's market and when price points are below $300,000, we have a seller's market, where we see much more activity.

The lending environment is still very favorable. Interest rates remain at historic lows. It's a great time to buy a home because affordability levels are much lower than they have been in the past. 

It is also a great time to sell a home, as we are seeing a tremendous amount of buyer activity across the board. If you are thinking about selling your home, it's never too early to start planning.


If you have any questions regarding the Albany real estate market or real estate in general, please give us a call. We would be delighted to assist you.

link.title: Albany Real Estate Market Update for August 2014
